<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 207, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 186, 905, 200]]<|/det|>
0625/23  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 208, 905, 222]]<|/det|>
May/June 2017  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[813, 229, 905, 243]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 248, 588, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 312, 388, 328]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 518, 764, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 533, 465, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 549, 358, 563]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 563, 630, 578]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 798, 90]]<|/det|>
What is the most accurate and precise method to measure the thickness of a coin?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 117]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 415, 118]]<|/det|>
Use a micrometer screw gauge.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 134, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 125, 556, 144]]<|/det|>
Use a ruler and look at the scale perpendicularly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 134, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 152, 346, 170]]<|/det|>
Use a top pan balance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 178, 690, 196]]<|/det|>
Use the displacement method with water in a measuring cylinder.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 223, 97, 241]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 920, 256]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|> Light travels in a vacuum and then enters a glass block. The speed of the light in the glass block is \(2.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 546, 135]]<|/det|> Which statement about the speed of light is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 145, 134, 163]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 145, 636, 163]]<|/det|> The speed in a vacuum is 1.5 times the speed in the glass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 172, 134, 191]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 172, 662, 190]]<|/det|> The speed in the glass is the same as the speed in a vacuum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 199, 131, 217]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 199, 636, 217]]<|/det|> The speed in the glass is 1.5 times the speed in a vacuum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 225, 133, 243]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 225, 685, 243]]<|/det|> The speed in the glass is \(1.0 \times 10^{8}\) times the speed in a vacuum. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 270, 106, 288]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 270, 920, 303]]<|/det|> A fire alarm is not loud enough and the pitch is too low. An engineer adjusts the alarm so that it produces a louder note of a higher pitch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 777, 330]]<|/det|> What effect does this have on the amplitude and on the frequency of the sound? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 342, 430, 470]]<|/det|>
amplitudefrequency
Alargergreater
Blargersmaller
Csmallergreater
Dsmallersmaller
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 498, 107, 515]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 497, 626, 515]]<|/det|> In which way are a bar magnet and an electromagnet similar? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 526, 133, 545]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 526, 757, 545]]<|/det|> A bar magnet and an electromagnet are always magnetised when stored. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 553, 131, 571]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 553, 920, 586]]<|/det|> A bar magnet and an electromagnet can both be used to separate magnetic and non-magnetic materials. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 594, 133, 612]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 594, 777, 612]]<|/det|> A bar magnet can be made of steel and an electromagnet uses a steel core. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 621, 133, 638]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 621, 881, 638]]<|/det|> The magnetic field strength of a bar magnet and of an electromagnet can both be varied. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 664, 106, 682]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 664, 850, 682]]<|/det|> A magnet near a coil of wire is attracted to the coil only when there is a current in the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 694, 524, 712]]<|/det|> Which statement explains this force of attraction? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 721, 133, 740]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 721, 527, 740]]<|/det|> The coil of wire has its own gravitational field. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 749, 133, 766]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 749, 470, 766]]<|/det|> The coil of wire is made from soft iron. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 775, 133, 794]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 775, 599, 792]]<|/det|> The current in the coil of wire creates a magnetic field. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 801, 133, 819]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 801, 667, 819]]<|/det|> The current in the coil of wire induces a charge on the magnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 551, 89]]<|/det|>
A steel magnet is placed in a coil and demagnetised.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 776, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 134, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 688, 147]]<|/det|>
a direct current in the coil, then reduce the current quickly to zero

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 133, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 682, 175]]<|/det|>
a direct current in the coil, then reduce the current slowly to zero

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 131, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 740, 201]]<|/det|>
an alternating current in the coil, then reduce the current quickly to zero

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 209, 732, 227]]<|/det|>
an alternating current in the coil, then reduce the current slowly to zero

brass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 308, 133, 327]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 308, 200, 325]]<|/det|>
glass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 335, 133, 353]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 335, 210, 352]]<|/det|>
plastic

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 361, 133, 378]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 361, 200, 378]]<|/det|>
wood

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 652, 134, 670]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 652, 390, 670]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 599, 89]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a circuit used to make a light detector. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 98, 611, 222]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 235, 512, 253]]<|/det|> One component is connected between X and Y. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 265, 841, 282]]<|/det|> Which component causes the ammeter reading to increase when the light gets brighter? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 295, 230, 314]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 317, 278, 356]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 295, 413, 314]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 317, 465, 356]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[579, 295, 598, 314]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[524, 317, 648, 356]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[761, 295, 781, 314]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[712, 325, 836, 363]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 392, 106, 410]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 392, 489, 410]]<|/det|> A truth table for a type of logic gate is shown. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 420, 675, 549]]<|/det|>
input 1input 2output
000
011
101
111
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 561, 361, 579]]<|/det|> Which type of logic gate is it? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 590, 134, 607]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 590, 196, 607]]<|/det|> AND <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 590, 303, 607]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[310, 590, 364, 607]]<|/det|> NOR <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 590, 470, 607]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 590, 529, 607]]<|/det|> NOT <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 590, 636, 607]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 590, 685, 607]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 635, 107, 653]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 635, 715, 653]]<|/det|> In which device is a split-ring commutator used, and what is its purpose? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 664, 611, 853]]<|/det|>
devicepurpose
Aa.c. generatorto change the direction of the current in the coil as it turns
Ba.c. generatorto change the output current from d.c. into a.c.
Cd.c. motorto change the direction of the current in the coil as it turns
Dd.c. motorto change the input current from a.c. into d.c.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>36</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 376, 90]]<|/det|>
What is the purpose of a relay?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 133, 118]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 527, 119]]<|/det|>
to change a large voltage into a small voltage

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 133, 144]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 527, 144]]<|/det|>
to change a small voltage into a large voltage

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 153, 133, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 152, 561, 170]]<|/det|>
to use a large current to switch on a small current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 178, 561, 196]]<|/det|>
to use a small current to switch on a large current

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 223, 106, 242]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 223, 843, 242]]<|/det|>
When a source of \(\alpha\) -particles is directed towards a thin metal foil they become scattered.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 253, 821, 272]]<|/det|>
Which observation of this experiment provides evidence for a small charged nucleus?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 282, 133, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 282, 878, 301]]<|/det|>
A small proportion of the \(\alpha\) -particles come straight back from the foil towards the source.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 312, 133, 330]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 312, 690, 330]]<|/det|>
A small proportion of the \(\alpha\) -particles pass straight through the foil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 339, 133, 358]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 339, 698, 357]]<|/det|>
Some of the \(\alpha\) -particles are deflected by an angle of less than \(90^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 367, 133, 384]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 367, 688, 384]]<|/det|>
Some of the \(\alpha\) -particles follow a curved path after leaving the foil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 411, 107, 429]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 411, 584, 429]]<|/det|>
Which description of a neutral atom of copper is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 440, 133, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 440, 440, 457]]<|/det|>
a nucleus surrounded by electrons

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 467, 133, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 467, 447, 484]]<|/det|>
a nucleus surrounded by molecules

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 494, 133, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 494, 440, 510]]<|/det|>
electrons surrounded by a nucleus

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 520, 133, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 520, 442, 537]]<|/det|>
electrons surrounded by molecules

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 562, 107, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 562, 480, 581]]<|/det|>
A sample of radioactive isotope is decaying.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 592, 460, 610]]<|/det|>
The nuclei of which atoms will decay first?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 621, 133, 638]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 621, 662, 638]]<|/det|>
It is impossible to know because radioactive decay is random.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 648, 133, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 648, 675, 665]]<|/det|>
It is impossible to know unless the age of the material is known.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 675, 133, 692]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 675, 871, 692]]<|/det|>
The atoms near the centre will decay first because they are surrounded by more atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 700, 133, 718]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 700, 890, 718]]<|/det|>
The atoms near the surface will decay first because the radiation can escape more easily.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 591, 89]]<|/det|>
A student determines the half-life of a radioactive isotope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
The student uses a detector over five minutes and plots a graph showing how the count rate shown on the detector varies with time.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 675, 165]]<|/det|>
The count rate due to background radiation is 30 counts per minute.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 175, 833, 395]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 410, 408, 428]]<|/det|>
What is the half-life of this isotope?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 439, 139, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 439, 262, 457]]<|/det|>
0.30 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 466, 133, 484]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 466, 253, 484]]<|/det|>
1.2 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 492, 133, 510]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 492, 253, 510]]<|/det|>
1.5 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 518, 133, 536]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 518, 253, 536]]<|/det|>
5.0 minutes
